headers.toc1: The Book of the Prophet Jeremiah
headers.mt1: The Book of the Prophet Jeremiah

verses.text:
The words of Jeremiah the son of Hilkiah, of the priests that
\add were\add* in Anathoth in the land of Benjamin:

To whom the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came in the days of Josiah
the son of Amon king of Judah, in the thirteenth year of his reign.

It came also in the days of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king
of Judah, unto the end of the eleventh year of Zedekiah the son of
Josiah king of Judah, unto the carrying away of Jerusalem captive
in the fifth month.
Then the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came unto me, saying,

Before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee; and before thou camest
forth out of the womb I sanctified thee, \add and\add* I ordained
thee a prophet unto the nations.\f + \fr 1.5  \ft ordained: Heb.
gave\f*

Then said I, Ah, Lord \nd GOD\nd*! behold, I cannot speak: for I
\add am\add* a child.

¶ But the \nd LORD\nd* said unto me, Say not, I \add am\add*
a child: for thou shalt go to all that I shall send thee, and whatsoever I
command thee thou shalt speak.

Be not afraid of their faces: for I \add am\add* with thee to
deliver thee, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.

Then the 
d LORD
d* put forth his hand, and touched my mouth.
And the 
d LORD
d* said unto me, Behold, I have put my words in thy
mouth.

See, I have this day set thee over the nations and over the
kingdoms, to root out, and to pull down, and to destroy, and to throw
down, to build, and to plant.

¶ Moreover the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came unto me, saying,
Jeremiah, what seest thou? And I said, I see a rod of an almond tree.

Then said the \nd LORD\nd* unto me, Thou hast well seen: for I will
hasten my word to perform it.

And the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came unto me the second time,
saying, What seest thou? And I said, I see a seething pot; and the
face thereof \add is\add* toward the north.\f + \fr 1.13  \ft toward…: Heb. from the face of the
north\f*

Then the \nd LORD\nd* said unto me, Out of the north an evil
shall break forth upon all the inhabitants of the land.\f + \fr 1.14 
\ft shall…: Heb. shall be opened\f*

For, lo, I will call all the families of the kingdoms of the
north, saith the \nd LORD\nd*; and they shall come, and they shall
set every one his throne at the entering of the gates of Jerusalem,
and against all the walls thereof round about, and against all the
cities of Judah.

And I will utter my judgments against them touching all their
wickedness, who have forsaken me, and have burned incense unto other
gods, and worshipped the works of their own hands.

¶ Thou therefore gird up thy loins, and arise, and speak unto them all that I
command thee: be not dismayed at their faces, lest I confound thee
before them.\f + \fr 1.17  \ft confound: or, break to pieces\f*

For, behold, I have made thee this day a defenced city, and an
iron pillar, and brasen walls against the whole land, against the
kings of Judah, against the princes thereof, against the priests
thereof, and against the people of the land.

And they shall fight against thee; but they shall not prevail against thee; for I
\add am\add* with thee, saith the \nd LORD\nd*, to deliver thee.
Moreover the word of the \nd LORD\nd* came to me, saying,

Go and cry in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, Thus saith the
\nd LORD\nd*; I remember thee, the kindness of thy youth, the love
of thine espousals, when thou wentest after me in the wilderness,
in a land \add that was\add* not sown.\f + \fr 2.2  \ft thee: or, for thy
sake\f*

Israel \add was\add* holiness unto the 
d LORD
d*, \add and\add*
the firstfruits of his increase: all that devour him shall offend;
evil shall come upon them, saith the 
d LORD
d*.

Hear ye the word of the \nd LORD\nd*, O house of Jacob, and all the
families of the house of Israel:

¶ Thus saith the \nd LORD\nd*, What iniquity have your fathers
found in me, that they are gone far from me, and have walked after
vanity, and are become vain?

Neither said they, Where \add is\add* the \nd LORD\nd* that brought us
up out of the land of Egypt, that led us through the wilderness,
through a land of deserts and of pits, through a land of drought,
and of the shadow of death, through a land that no man passed through,
and where no man dwelt?

And I brought you into a plentiful country, to eat the fruit
thereof and the goodness thereof; but when ye entered, ye defiled
my land, and made mine heritage an abomination.\f + \fr 2.7  \ft a plentiful…: or, the land of
Carmel\f*

The priests said not, Where \add is\add* the \nd LORD\nd*?
and they that handle the law knew me not: the pastors also transgressed
against me, and the prophets prophesied by Baal, and walked after
\add things that\add* do not profit.

¶ Wherefore I will yet plead with you, saith the \nd LORD\nd*,
and with your children’s children will I plead.

For pass over the isles of Chittim, and see; and send unto
Kedar, and consider diligently, and see if there be such a thing.\f + \fr 2.10 
\ft over: or, over to\f*

Hath a nation changed \add their\add* gods, which \add are\add*
yet no gods? but my people have changed their glory for \add that
which\add* doth not profit.

Be astonished, O ye heavens, at this, and be horribly afraid,
be ye very desolate, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.

For my people have committed two evils; they have forsaken
me the fountain of living waters, \add and\add* hewed them out cisterns,
broken cisterns, that can hold no water.

¶ \add Is\add* Israel a servant? \add is\add* he a homeborn
\add slave\add*? why is he spoiled?\f + \fr 2.14  \ft spoiled: Heb. become a
spoil?\f*

The young lions roared upon him, \add and\add* yelled, and they
made his land waste: his cities are burned without inhabitant.\f + \fr 2.15 
\ft yelled: Heb. gave out their voice\f*

Also the children of Noph and Tahapanes have broken the crown of thy
head.\f + \fr 2.16  \ft have…: or, feed on thy crown\f*

Hast thou not procured this unto thyself, in that thou hast
forsaken the \nd LORD\nd* thy God, when he led thee by the way?

And now what hast thou to do in the way of Egypt, to drink
the waters of Sihor? or what hast thou to do in the way of Assyria,
to drink the waters of the river?

Thine own wickedness shall correct thee, and thy backslidings
shall reprove thee: know therefore and see that \add it is\add* an
evil \add thing\add* and bitter, that thou hast forsaken the \nd LORD\nd*
thy God, and that my fear \add is\add* not in thee, saith the Lord
\nd GOD\nd* of hosts.

¶ For of old time I have broken thy yoke, \add and\add* burst
thy bands; and thou saidst, I will not transgress; when upon every
high hill and under every green tree thou wanderest, playing the
harlot.\f + \fr 2.20  \ft transgress: or, serve\f*

Yet I had planted thee a noble vine, wholly a right seed:
how then art thou turned into the degenerate plant of a strange vine unto me?

For though thou wash thee with nitre, and take thee much soap,
\add yet\add* thine iniquity is marked before me, saith the Lord
\nd GOD\nd*.

How canst thou say, I am not polluted, I have not gone after
Baalim? see thy way in the valley, know what thou hast done: \add thou
art\add* a swift dromedary traversing her ways;\f + \fr 2.23  \ft thou art…: or, O swift
dromedary\f*

A wild ass used to the wilderness, \add that\add* snuffeth
up the wind at her pleasure; in her occasion who can turn her away?
all they that seek her will not weary themselves; in her month they shall
find her.\f + \fr 2.24  \ft A wild…: or, O wild ass, etc\f*\f + \fr 2.24 
\ft used: Heb. taught\f*\f + \fr 2.24  \ft her pleasure: Heb. the desire of her
heart\f*\f + \fr 2.24  \ft turn…: or, reverse it?\f*

Withhold thy foot from being unshod, and thy throat from thirst:
but thou saidst, There is no hope: no; for I have loved strangers,
and after them will I go.\f + \fr 2.25  \ft There…: or, Is the case
desperate?\f*

As the thief is ashamed when he is found, so is the house
of Israel ashamed; they, their kings, their princes, and their priests,
and their prophets,

Saying to a stock, Thou \add art\add* my father; and to a
stone, Thou hast brought me forth: for they have turned \add their\add*
back unto me, and not \add their\add* face: but in the time of their
trouble they will say, Arise, and save us.\f + \fr 2.27  \ft brought…: or, begotten
me\f*\f + \fr 2.27  \ft their back: Heb. the hinder part of the neck\f*

But where \add are\add* thy gods that thou hast made thee? let them
arise, if they can save thee in the time of thy trouble: for \add according
to\add* the number of thy cities are thy gods, O Judah.\f + \fr 2.28 
\ft trouble: Heb. evil\f*

Wherefore will ye plead with me? ye all have transgressed
against me, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.

In vain have I smitten your children; they received no correction:
your own sword hath devoured your prophets, like a destroying lion.

¶ O generation, see ye the word of the \nd LORD\nd*. Have I been a
wilderness unto Israel? a land of darkness? wherefore say my people,
We are lords; we will come no more unto thee?\f + \fr 2.31  \ft We are…: Heb. We have
dominion\f*

Can a maid forget her ornaments, \add or\add* a bride her
attire? yet my people have forgotten me days without number.

Why trimmest thou thy way to seek love? therefore hast thou also
taught the wicked ones thy ways.

Also in thy skirts is found the blood of the souls of the
poor innocents: I have not found it by secret search, but upon all
these.\f + \fr 2.34  \ft secret…: Heb. digging\f*

Yet thou sayest, Because I am innocent, surely his anger shall
turn from me. Behold, I will plead with thee, because thou sayest,
I have not sinned.

Why gaddest thou about so much to change thy way? thou also shalt be
ashamed of Egypt, as thou wast ashamed of Assyria.

Yea, thou shalt go forth from him, and thine hands upon thine
head: for the \nd LORD\nd* hath rejected thy confidences, and thou shalt not
prosper in them.

They say, If a man put away his wife, and she go from him, and become
another man’s, shall he return unto her again? shall not that land
be greatly polluted? but thou hast played the harlot with many lovers;
yet return again to me, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 3.1  \ft They say: Heb.
Saying\f*

Lift up thine eyes unto the high places, and see where thou hast not been
lien with. In the ways hast thou sat for them, as the Arabian in the
wilderness; and thou hast polluted the land with thy whoredoms and with thy
wickedness.

Therefore the showers have been withholden, and there hath been no latter
rain; and thou hadst a whore’s forehead, thou refusedst to be ashamed.

Wilt thou not from this time cry unto me, My father, thou \add art\add*
the guide of my youth?

Will he reserve \add his anger\add* for ever? will he keep
\add it\add* to the end? Behold, thou hast spoken and done evil things
as thou couldest.

¶ The \nd LORD\nd* said also unto me in the days of Josiah the
king, Hast thou seen \add that\add* which backsliding Israel hath
done? she is gone up upon every high mountain and under every green
tree, and there hath played the harlot.

And I said after she had done all these \add things\add*, Turn
thou unto me. But she returned not. And her treacherous sister Judah
saw \add it\add*.

And I saw, when for all the causes whereby backsliding Israel
committed adultery I had put her away, and given her a bill of divorce;
yet her treacherous sister Judah feared not, but went and played the
harlot also.

And it came to pass through the lightness of her whoredom,
that she defiled the land, and committed adultery with stones and with
stocks.\f + \fr 3.9  \ft lightness: or, fame\f*

And yet for all this her treacherous sister Judah hath not
turned unto me with her whole heart, but feignedly, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 3.10 
\ft feignedly: Heb. in falsehood\f*

And the \nd LORD\nd* said unto me, The backsliding Israel
hath justified herself more than treacherous Judah.

¶ Go and proclaim these words toward the north, and say, Return,
thou backsliding Israel, saith the \nd LORD\nd*; \add and\add* I will not cause mine
anger to fall upon you: for I \add am\add* merciful, saith the \nd LORD\nd*,
\add and\add* I will not keep \add anger\add* for ever.

Only acknowledge thine iniquity, that thou hast transgressed
against the \nd LORD\nd* thy God, and hast scattered thy ways to the
strangers under every green tree, and ye have not obeyed my voice,
saith the \nd LORD\nd*.

Turn, O backsliding children, saith the \nd LORD\nd*; for I am
married unto you: and I will take you one of a city, and two of a
family, and I will bring you to Zion:

And I will give you pastors according to mine heart, which shall
feed you with knowledge and understanding.

And it shall come to pass, when ye be multiplied and increased
in the land, in those days, saith the \nd LORD\nd*, they shall say
no more, The ark of the covenant of the \nd LORD\nd*: neither shall it
come to mind: neither shall they remember it; neither shall they
visit \add it;\add* neither shall \add that\add* be done any more.\f + \fr 3.16 
\ft come to mind: Heb. come upon the heart\f*\f + \fr 3.16  \ft that…: or, it be
magnified\f*

At that time they shall call Jerusalem the throne of the \nd LORD\nd*;
and all the nations shall be gathered unto it, to the name of the
\nd LORD\nd*, to Jerusalem: neither shall they walk any more after
the imagination of their evil heart.\f + \fr 3.17  \ft imagination: or,
stubbornness\f*

In those days the house of Judah shall walk with the house
of Israel, and they shall come together out of the land of the north
to the land that I have given for an inheritance unto your fathers.\f + \fr 3.18 
\ft with: or, to\f*\f + \fr 3.18  \ft given…: or, caused your fathers to
possess\f*

But I said, How shall I put thee among the children, and give
thee a pleasant land, a goodly heritage of the hosts of nations?
and I said, Thou shalt call me, My father; and shalt not turn away
from me.\f + \fr 3.19  \ft from me: Heb. from after me\f*\f + \fr 3.19 
\ft a goodly…: Heb. an heritage of glory, or, beauty\f*\f + \fr 3.19 
\ft pleasant…: Heb. land of desire\f*

¶ Surely \add as\add* a wife treacherously departeth from her
husband, so have ye dealt treacherously with me, O house of Israel,
saith the \nd LORD\nd*.\f + \fr 3.20  \ft husband: Heb. friend\f*

A voice was heard upon the high places, weeping \add and\add*
supplications of the children of Israel: for they have perverted
their way, \add and\add* they have forgotten the \nd LORD\nd* their
God.

Return, ye backsliding children, \add and\add* I will heal
your backslidings. Behold, we come unto thee; for thou \add art\add*
the \nd LORD\nd* our God.

Truly in vain \add is salvation hoped for\add* from the hills,
\add and from\add* the multitude of mountains: truly in the \nd LORD\nd*
our God \add is\add* the salvation of Israel.

For shame hath devoured the labour of our fathers from our
youth; their flocks and their herds, their sons and their daughters.

We lie down in our shame, and our confusion covereth us: for we have
sinned against the \nd LORD\nd* our God, we and our fathers, from our
youth even unto this day, and have not obeyed the voice of the \nd LORD\nd*
our God.

If thou wilt return, O Israel, saith the \nd LORD\nd*, return
unto me: and if thou wilt put away thine abominations out of my sight,
then shalt thou not remove.

And thou shalt swear, The \nd LORD\nd* liveth, in truth, in
judgment, and in righteousness; and the nations shall bless themselves in him, and in him shall they
glory.

¶ For thus saith the \nd LORD\nd* to the men of Judah and Jerusalem,
Break up your fallow ground, and sow not among thorns.

Circumcise yourselves to the \nd LORD\nd*, and take away the
foreskins of your heart, ye men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem:
lest my fury come forth like fire, and burn that none can quench
\add it\add*, because of the evil of your doings.

Declare ye in Judah, and publish in Jerusalem; and say, Blow
ye the trumpet in the land: cry, gather together, and say, Assemble
yourselves, and let us go into the defenced cities.

Set up the standard toward Zion: retire, stay not: for I will
bring evil from the north, and a great destruction.\f + \fr 4.6 
\ft retire: or, strengthen\f*\f + \fr 4.6  \ft destruction: Heb.
breaking\f*

The lion is come up from his thicket, and the destroyer of the
Gentiles is on his way; he is gone forth from his place to make thy
land desolate; \add and\add* thy cities shall be laid waste, without an
inhabitant.

For this gird you with sackcloth, lament and howl: for the
fierce anger of the \nd LORD\nd* is not turned back from us.

And it shall come to pass at that day, saith the \nd LORD\nd*,
\add that\add* the heart of the king shall perish, and the heart
of the princes; and the priests shall be astonished, and the prophets
shall wonder.

At that time shall it be said to this people and to Jerusalem,
A dry wind of the high places in the wilderness toward the daughter
of my people, not to fan, nor to cleanse,

\add Even\add* a full wind from those \add places\add* shall
come unto me: now also will I give sentence against them.\f + \fr 4.12 
\ft a full…: or, a fuller wind than those\f*\f + \fr 4.12  \ft give…: Heb. utter
judgments\f*

Behold, he shall come up as clouds, and his chariots \add shall
be\add* as a whirlwind: his horses are swifter than eagles. Woe unto us! for we are
spoiled.

O Jerusalem, wash thine heart from wickedness, that thou mayest be
saved. How long shall thy vain thoughts lodge within thee?

For a voice declareth from Dan, and publisheth affliction
from mount Ephraim.

Make ye mention to the nations; behold, publish against Jerusalem,
\add that\add* watchers come from a far country, and give out their
voice against the cities of Judah.

As keepers of a field, are they against her round about; because she hath been
rebellious against me, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.

Thy way and thy doings have procured these \add things\add* unto thee; this
\add is\add* thy wickedness, because it is bitter, because it reacheth
unto thine heart.

¶ My bowels, my bowels! I am pained at my very heart; my heart
maketh a noise in me; I cannot hold my peace, because thou hast heard,
O my soul, the sound of the trumpet, the alarm of war.\f + \fr 4.19 
\ft my very…: Heb. the walls of my heart\f*

Destruction upon destruction is cried; for the whole land
is spoiled: suddenly are my tents spoiled, \add and\add* my curtains
in a moment.

How long shall I see the standard, \add and\add* hear the
sound of the trumpet?

For my people \add is\add* foolish, they have not known me; they
\add are\add* sottish children, and they have none understanding: they
\add are\add* wise to do evil, but to do good they have no knowledge.

I beheld the earth, and, lo, \add it was\add* without form,
and void; and the heavens, and they \add had\add* no light.

I beheld the mountains, and, lo, they trembled, and all the
hills moved lightly.

I beheld, and, lo, \add there was\add* no man, and all the
birds of the heavens were fled.

I beheld, and, lo, the fruitful place \add was\add* a wilderness,
and all the cities thereof were broken down at the presence of the
\nd LORD\nd*, \add and\add* by his fierce anger.

For thus hath the \nd LORD\nd* said, The whole land shall be
desolate; yet will I not make a full end.

For this shall the earth mourn, and the heavens above be black:
because I have spoken \add it\add*, I have purposed \add it\add*,
and will not repent, neither will I turn back from it.

The whole city shall flee for the noise of the horsemen and
bowmen; they shall go into thickets, and climb up upon the rocks:
every city \add shall be\add* forsaken, and not a man dwell therein.

And \add when\add* thou \add art\add* spoiled, what wilt thou
do? Though thou clothest thyself with crimson, though thou deckest
thee with ornaments of gold, though thou rentest thy face with painting,
in vain shalt thou make thyself fair; \add thy\add* lovers will despise
thee, they will seek thy life.\f + \fr 4.30  \ft face: Heb. eyes\f*

For I have heard a voice as of a woman in travail, \add and\add*
the anguish as of her that bringeth forth her first child, the voice
of the daughter of Zion, \add that\add* bewaileth herself, \add that\add*
spreadeth her hands, \add saying\add*, Woe \add is\add* me now! for my
soul is wearied because of murderers.

Run ye to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem, and see
now, and know, and seek in the broad places thereof, if ye can find
a man, if there be \add any\add* that executeth judgment, that seeketh
the truth; and I will pardon it.

And though they say, The \nd LORD\nd* liveth; surely they swear
falsely.

O \nd LORD\nd*, \add are\add* not thine eyes upon the truth?
thou hast stricken them, but they have not grieved; thou hast consumed them,
\add but\add* they have refused to receive correction: they have made their
faces harder than a rock; they have refused to return.

Therefore I said, Surely these \add are\add* poor; they are
foolish: for they know not the way of the \nd LORD\nd*, \add nor\add*
the judgment of their God.

I will get me unto the great men, and will speak unto them; for they have
known the way of the \nd LORD\nd*, \add and\add* the judgment of their
God: but these have altogether broken the yoke, \add and\add* burst
the bonds.

Wherefore a lion out of the forest shall slay them, \add and\add*
a wolf of the evenings shall spoil them, a leopard shall watch over their
cities: every one that goeth out thence shall be torn in pieces:
because their transgressions are many, \add and\add* their backslidings
are increased.\f + \fr 5.6  \ft evenings: or, deserts\f*\f + \fr 5.6 
\ft are increased: Heb. are strong\f*

¶ How shall I pardon thee for this? thy children have forsaken
me, and sworn by \add them that are\add* no gods: when I had fed them to the
full, they then committed adultery, and assembled themselves by troops
in the harlots’ houses.

They were \add as\add* fed horses in the morning: every one
neighed after his neighbour’s wife.

Shall I not visit for these \add things\add*? saith the \nd LORD\nd*:
and shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?

¶ Go ye up upon her walls, and destroy; but make not a full
end: take away her battlements; for they \add are\add* not the \nd LORD’s\nd*.

For the house of Israel and the house of Judah have dealt
very treacherously against me, saith the \nd LORD\nd*.

They have belied the \nd LORD\nd*, and said, \add It is\add*
not he; neither shall evil come upon us; neither shall we see sword
nor famine:

And the prophets shall become wind, and the word \add is\add*
not in them: thus shall it be done unto them.

Wherefore thus saith the \nd LORD\nd* God of hosts, Because ye
speak this word, behold, I will make my words in thy mouth fire,
and this people wood, and it shall devour them.

Lo, I will bring a nation upon you from far, O house of Israel,
saith the \nd LORD\nd*: it \add is\add* a mighty nation, it \add is\add*
an ancient nation, a nation whose language thou knowest not, neither
understandest what they say.

Their quiver \add is\add* as an open sepulchre, they \add are\add*
all mighty men.

And they shall eat up thine harvest, and thy bread, \add which\add*
thy sons and thy daughters should eat: they shall eat up thy flocks
and thine herds: they shall eat up thy vines and thy fig trees: they shall
impoverish thy fenced cities, wherein thou trustedst, with the sword.

Nevertheless in those days, saith the \nd LORD\nd*, I will not
make a full end with you.

¶ And it shall come to pass, when ye shall say, Wherefore doeth
the \nd LORD\nd* our God all these \add things\add* unto us? then shalt thou
answer them, Like as ye have forsaken me, and served strange gods
in your land, so shall ye serve strangers in a land \add that is\add* not yours.

Declare this in the house of Jacob, and publish it in Judah,
saying,

Fear ye not me? saith the \nd LORD\nd*: will ye not tremble
at my presence, which have placed the sand \add for\add* the bound
of the sea by a perpetual decree, that it cannot pass it: and though the
waves thereof toss themselves, yet can they not prevail; though they
roar, yet can they not pass over it?

But this people hath a revolting and a rebellious heart; they are
revolted and gone.

Neither say they in their heart, Let us now fear the \nd LORD\nd*
our God, that giveth rain, both the former and the latter, in his
season: he reserveth unto us the appointed weeks of the harvest.

¶ Your iniquities have turned away these \add things\add*,
and your sins have withholden good \add things\add* from you.

For among my people are found wicked \add men:\add* they lay
wait, as he that setteth snares; they set a trap, they catch men.\f + \fr 5.26 
\ft they lay…: or, they pry as fowlers lie in wait\f*

As a cage is full of birds, so \add are\add* their houses
full of deceit: therefore they are become great, and waxen rich.\f + \fr 5.27 
\ft cage: or, coop\f*

They are waxen fat, they shine: yea, they overpass the deeds
of the wicked: they judge not the cause, the cause of the fatherless,
yet they prosper; and the right of the needy do they not judge.

Shall I not visit for these \add things\add*? saith the \nd LORD\nd*:
shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?

¶ A wonderful and horrible thing is committed in the land;\f + \fr 5.30 
\ft A wonderful…: or, Astonishment and filthiness\f*

The prophets prophesy falsely, and the priests bear rule by their
means; and my people love \add to have it\add* so: and what will ye
do in the end thereof?\f + \fr 5.31  \ft bear…: or, take into their
hands\f*

O ye children of Benjamin, gather yourselves to flee out of the
midst of Jerusalem, and blow the trumpet in Tekoa, and set up a sign
of fire in Beth-haccerem: for evil appeareth out of the north, and
great destruction.

I have likened the daughter of Zion to a comely and delicate
\add woman\add*.\f + \fr 6.2  \ft comely: or, dwelling at home\f*

The shepherds with their flocks shall come unto her; they shall
pitch \add their\add* tents against her round about; they shall feed
